awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tracking the Subtropical Front across the Mid Pleistocene Transition Using Sea Surface Temperature and Nutrients
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to reconstruct changes in the position of the Subtropical Front (STF) in the Agulhas region of the Southern Ocean south of Africa over the last 1.5 million years. Ocean currents play a significant role in the distribution of heat and salt in the global ocean. Ultimately, changes in these currents influence marine nutrient distribution, ocean uptake of atmospheric CO2, and global climate. South of Africa, the Agulhas Current moves warm, salty water from the southern Indian Ocean into the South Atlantic Ocean. However, during intervals of near-global cooling, it is thought that the amount of this warm water escaping around Africa decreases or is even stopped, cutoff by a northward migration of the STF. Because a northward shift of the STF has the potential to both expand the surface area of the Southern Ocean and limit water exchange between the Indian and Atlantic Oceans, the region south of Africa is an important climate target to advance our understanding of how the physical movements of the STF may impact regional and global climate. Migrations of the STF are relatively poorly resolved for the past 1.5 million years, in part due to a prior lack of sediment cores in the critical region of front migration. This research combines multiple proxy records of ocean changes at a location sensitive to STF position to study how STF movement may have influenced ocean circulation and CO2 uptake. The project will support two female PIs (one early career) as well as two graduate students and several undergraduates. Broader public outreach is planned in the context of K-12 classroom and web-based materials.

The investigators will generate an integrated reconstruction of upper ocean dynamics along the Subtropical Front over the last 1.5 million years from sediments in a new International Ocean Discovery Program core (Site U1475) recovered from the southern Indian Ocean at a location well suited to monitor STF position. They will use multiple sediment proxies to generate an integrated reconstruction of upper ocean dynamics along the STF using reconstructions of water temperature, export production, and nutrient utilization. North-south migrations of the STF have been hypothesized to control movement of water through the Indo-Atlantic Gateway, an exchange that has important implications for the air-sea balance of CO2 and the strength of the meridional overturning circulation of the Atlantic. The resulting data will be used to document the location of the STF with respect to the core site and the nutrient status of the subantarctic region of the Southern Ocean during episodes of expansion. Specifically, the investigators will produce new high-resolution records of water temperature (using Uk37, TEX86, and foraminiferal census counts using a Modern Analog Technique), export production (using total organic carbon, biogenic silica, and total alkenone (C37tot) content), and nutrient dynamics (using foraminiferal-bound organic matter d15N) for the last 1.5 million years to constrain the history of the STF and its response to climate change. Emphasis will be placed on the Mid Pleistocene Transition (MPT), the time interval between 1.25 and 0.7 million years ago when the dominant periodicity of climate cycles changed from 41 kiloyears to 100 kiloyears in the absence of substantial change in orbital forcing. Reconstructing the location of the STF across the MPT is key to understanding the role that STF migration may have played in altering the Southern Ocean biological pump (with consequent changes in atmospheric CO2).

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to understand migrations of the Subtropical Front (STF) at the Indian-Atlantic Ocean Gateway for the last 1.5 Ma, and better constrain the impact of these migrations on global ocean circulation and climate. Shifts in the STF reflect changes in the spatial extent of the Southern Ocean and control the magnitude of heat and salt transfer from the Indian to the Atlantic Oceans through Agulhas Leakage, with potential implications for the air-sea balance of CO2 and meridional overturning circulation.Using sediment cores collected from the southernmost site of International Ocean Discovery Program?s Expedition 361 (at the Agulhas Plateau), we examined the interval surrounding the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT, ~1 Ma), an important global climate transition with longer, higher amplitude glacial cycles. This project provided records of sea surface and near surface temperatures, export production, and nutrient dynamics to reconstruct the migration of the Subtropical Front over the Agulhas Plateau. Foraminiferal nitrogen isotope records suggest that the nutrient dynamics at the Subtropical Front are a function of surface water masses and that the mix of nutrient-poor subtropical waters and nutrient-richer subpolar waters mixed in variable proportions through time. We found that the latitudinal position of the STF exhibited both a long term northward shift around 900 ka as well as glacial-interglacial variability. Northward migrations of the STF during glacials and after the MPT suggest that the surface area of the Southern Ocean expands significantly during cooling. The most dramatic migration documented in the N isotope record was the southward migrations during the super interglacial period Marine Isotope State 31. 
These results suggest that the expansion of the Southern Ocean during the MPT may have modified the global climate through the systems impact on global ocean circulation. By comparing to records across the Southern Ocean, we also demonstrate that glacial nutrient delivery to the northernmost parts of the Southern Ocean decreased in the 600-900 ka time interval while nutrient utilization remained intense. This implies that nutrient drawdown shifted toward the south during 600-900 ka interval, where that C is more likely to be sequestered at depth.Understanding the locus of nutrient drawdown as well as the relative position of the STF will lead to a better understanding of the respective roles of physics and biology in regulating climate. The expansion of the Southern Ocean over the Agulhas Plateau and the intense delivery of cool, nutrient-rich water is consistent with the ideas that 1) Agulhas Leakage, the eddy-based delivery of heat and salt into the Atlantic, may have been reduced or 2) that entrainment of cold, fresh water supplied by the Southern Ocean may have increased during the MPT. In either case, the impact is similar, a reduction in salt and an increase in buoyancy which may impact meridional overturning in the NA. 
The broader impacts of this award focused on student education and mentoring, developing ocean-focused curricula, and communicating the excitement of ocean exploration with those outside of the university setting. The award supported multiple graduate and undergraduate students, broadening participation in ocean sciences from underrepresented groups. In addition to mentoring these students, supported participants joined university and national mentoring programs to encourage the next generations of scientists. University curricula on ocean dynamics was developed and introduced as a part of this award. Finally, beyond formal scientific presentations of the results, this research was discussed with the public at GSO?s open houses, through and art-science data visualization collaboration, and public talks. Data generated from this award are freely available to the public.
